Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Project: Development and Testing of a Secure Programming Clinic

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This capacity building project will create Secure Programming Clinic to enhance student learning and expertise in writing robust, secure software, analogous to a writing clinic in an English department or law school. It provides continual reinforcement of the mechanisms, methods, technologies, and need for programming with security and robustness considerations throughout a student's undergraduate coursework. The clinic would augment courses, not replace them or their content. The clinic can be tailored to meet the needs of specific groups, such as beginning students or students in a particular class. The students will likely retain and use some of these skills after they graduated, thereby improving the quality of software overall. In addition, the development of the assessment instruments to evaluate the impact of initial learning, abstraction, feedback, and meta-cognition on transfer will be a valuable contribution to computer science education researchers. The NSF's CyberCorpsÂ® SFS program funds projects that address cybersecurity education and workforce development. The Scholarship Track provides funding to award scholarships to students in cybersecurity. In return for their scholarships, recipients will work after graduation for a Federal, State, Local, or Tribal Government organization in a position related to cybersecurity for a period equal to the length of the scholarship. The Capacity Track seeks innovative proposals leading to an increase in the ability of the United States higher education enterprise to produce cybersecurity professionals.

The project will test the clinic's effectiveness by developing and validating measures that reflect the ability of learners to write robust, secure software. The clinic will be tried in several different ways to gather data, and use that data to evaluate each particular clinic. The clinic procedures, instructional modules and measures will be disseminated to the educational community. This project brings to bear research in learning in conjunction with methods used in other disciplines, particularly the humanities, which have proved successful in augmenting existing courses to provide reinforcement of basic skills. From this grounding, the Secure Programming Clinic seeks to build and assess expertise in an area that spans many aspects of programming. The project further studies how to deliver this information and practice; how to frame the information so students at different levels of programming experience and skill can benefit from them; and how to use the results of the evaluation to tune the clinic and materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this project were to: 1) develop a clinic to enhance student learning and expertise in writing robust, secure software;  2) develop and validate measures that reflect the ability of learners with regard to writing robust, secure software; 3) implement and evaluate the clinic; and 4) disseminate the clinic procedures, instructional modules and measures to the educational community.

This project was motivated by two primary problems viz. the lack of secure programming expertise that has resulted in software security failures, and the requirement to improve security education without adding to an already overloaded curriculum. The Secure Programming Clinic addressed these problems by giving students a mechanism to learn about secure programming and get feedback on the security/robustness aspects of their programs outside of class.

The clinic was envisioned as a dedicated physical space staffed by two clinicians. These clinicians were advanced students (usually graduate students) who would meet with less advanced students (usually undergraduate students) in-person or electronically to discuss their code. Students had the option to make appointments with clinicians or drop in during dedicated hours each week. The clinic was initially deployed at the University of California, Davis. It was then expanded to California State University, Sacramento; California Polytechnic State University, San Luis Obispo; and Purdue University, Northwest. In practice the clinic was implemented with slight variations by site and by term e.g. the instructor serving as the clinician, having one clinician instead of two, requiring students to get feedback from the clinic for specific assignments, and allowing students to get extra points on assignments as an incentive to visit the clinic.

Student visits to the clinic at each institution were tracked. The researchers developed a pre and post test to measure the impact of the clinic on secure programming learning. When not required, the majority of students visiting the clinic tended to be high performers or low performers. This could be explained as high performing students who are highly motivated and proactive would visit the clinic to further improve. Low performing students who were also proactive would visit the clinic to help pull up their grades. We also found that students who were already performing well showed the most improvement from visiting the clinic. This indicates that a level of pre-existing knowledge is necessary to improve. The majority of students found the existence of a clinic helpful and expressed satisfaction with clinic services.

In addition to the development and deployment of Secure Programming Clinics at several institutions, this project spurred additional research which resulted in four additional NSF and NSA funded projects. This project led to a Delphi study which mapped the extent of the field of secure programming, the development of a Secure Programming Concept Inventory to assess learning in secure programming, and the development of a website (http://spc.cs.ucdavis.edu/) where students from any institution can learn more about secure programming and where eventually students will be able to schedule appointments with clinicians regardless of whether a physical clinic exists at their institution. The project has also inspired the research team to develop an integrated computer adaptive test and intelligent tutoring system for secure programming.
